linkTarget.anchoringText: The Area of Review (AoR) for this work is located in northwest North Dakota (Fig. 1). A geomechanical analysis was conducted based on the data from three wells (Fig. 2). The Gamma Ray (GR) logs show a similar trend for the three wells with a down dip from north to south (Fig. 3). The GR of Well #1 was correlated to the North Dakota stratigraphic column prepared by Bluemle et al. (1986) to show the location of the injection horizon and confining unit in Dakota formation (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The injector is located in northwest North Dakota.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The injector is located in northwest North Dakota.

(1986) to show the location of the injection horizon and confining unit in Dakota formation (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Lithology sequence of well of Well #1.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Lithology sequence of well of Well #1.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The bottomhole pressure was calculated using Eq. 4 assuming a well diameter of 8.5" within the aquifer section of the formation. Each parameter study assumed: 50 years of injection, 10,000BPD (water), and a formation permeability of 350 – 1,000 mD with formation damage "skin factor" of 0 – 5 (Fig. 5). Fig. 6 shows the pressure distribution along the aquifer. Most of the pressure increase takes place in the first 50 ft from the wellbore.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Bottomhole pressure over 50 years of injection.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bottomhole pressure over 50 years of injection.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The bottomhole pressure was calculated using Eq. 4 assuming a well diameter of 8.5" within the aquifer section of the formation. Each parameter study assumed: 50 years of injection, 10,000BPD (water), and a formation permeability of 350 – 1,000 mD with formation damage "skin factor" of 0 – 5 (Fig. 5). Fig. 6 shows the pressure distribution along the aquifer. Most of the pressure increase takes place in the first 50 ft from the wellbore.

Geomechanical analyses were first conducted using using Advantek's log analysis software (@LogTM) applied to logs (Fig. 7) from Well #1. The goal in this case is to derive a set of mechanical properties along the injection well that allows us to determine when (or if) the formation will fracture; if a fracture is formed during injection, the analysis seeks to determine how the fracture itself would propagate (in particular, if the fracture would grow vertically through the containing layers).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Well log data from well #1 used to build the geochemical model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well log data from well #1 used to build the geochemical model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Average fracture pressures for the proposed injection interval in Inyan Kara sands are shown in Table 1. Detailed fracture pressures for the proposed injection interval are shown by Fig. 8.

The reservoir simulator showed that the reservoir can be divided into three regions during injection operations (Fig. 9). Inner region (displaced region) with brine composition equivalent to injected brine composition; middle region (transition region) where the injected and reservoir brines mixed together; outer region with composition of the reservoir brine.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Three regions can be identified during injection operations: a) injection fluid region (red zone); b) mixing region (yellow and green zones); c) untouched region (Blue zone). (Case #1)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Three regions can be identified during injection operations: a) injection fluid region (red zone); b) mixing region (yellow and green zones); c) untouched region (Blue zone). (Case #1)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The ratio of vertical to horizontal permeabilities (kz/kh) was assumed to be 0.1. The reservoir extended 10,000 feet in both x and y dimensions (Fig. 10) and constant pressure boundary conditions were used (with values set equal to the initial pore pressure). The injection wellbore was placed at the center of the aquifer and a neighboring offset well was noted to be approximately 0.25 miles from the point of injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: The aquifer model used to conduct the simulation study using REVEAL compositional reservoir simulator.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The aquifer model used to conduct the simulation study using REVEAL compositional reservoir simulator.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Assuming the injected waste has a temperature of 60°F and using the geothermal gradient, the calculated formation temperature is 120°F. The injected waste will tend to cool down a cylindrical volume around the wellbore (Fig. 11). Although the formation temperature decreased during the injection operations, the simulator does not predict any thermal fractures to be formed during the injection operation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Change in formation temperature due to injecting of 60°F waste into 120°F formation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Change in formation temperature due to injecting of 60°F waste into 120°F formation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Our results indicated that the permeability did not have any effect on the geochemical model – in particular, the concentrations of different ions and cations were identical for the two cases (Fig. 9). The higher permeability case showed a smaller radius of migration and a smaller transition region (Fig. 12). In both cases, migration extended further up-dip than down-dip. The only factor that the aquifer permeability affected is the formation permeability. Higher pressure values were noted at lower permeability case, which agrees with the results obtained in Fig. 5 (Figs. 13 & 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Thinner transition zone was noted at higher permeability.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thinner transition zone was noted at higher permeability.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Our results indicated that the permeability did not have any effect on the geochemical model – in particular, the concentrations of different ions and cations were identical for the two cases (Fig. 9). The higher permeability case showed a smaller radius of migration and a smaller transition region (Fig. 12). In both cases, migration extended further up-dip than down-dip. The only factor that the aquifer permeability affected is the formation permeability. Higher pressure values were noted at lower permeability case, which agrees with the results obtained in Fig. 5 (Figs. 13 & 14).

Our results indicated that the permeability did not have any effect on the geochemical model – in particular, the concentrations of different ions and cations were identical for the two cases (Fig. 9). The higher permeability case showed a smaller radius of migration and a smaller transition region (Fig. 12). In both cases, migration extended further up-dip than down-dip. The only factor that the aquifer permeability affected is the formation permeability. Higher pressure values were noted at lower permeability case, which agrees with the results obtained in Fig. 5 (Figs. 13 & 14).

Two cases were run assuming different confining layers permeability (0.18 and 1.5 × 10−6 mD). The results showed that even after 50 years of waste injection at 10,000 bpd the concentration of the tracer in the upper and lower confining layer is zero. No vertical flow will take place and all the fluids will tend to flow in the aquifer sands with no leakage (Figs. 15 & 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Mass Conc. of tracer in water @ kv =0.18 mD

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mass Conc. of tracer in water @ kv =0.18 mD

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Mass Conc. of tracer in water @ kv =1.5 × 10-6 mD.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mass Conc. of tracer in water @ kv =1.5 × 10-6 mD.
